Description.val:
Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) Family of Vehicles (FoV) is a joint U.S. Army and U.S. Marine Corps program, with the Army as lead service. JLTV is a FoV capable of performing multiple mission roles that provide protected, sustained, networked mobility for personnel and payloads across the full Range of Military Operations (ROMO).  JLTV features include increased protection and performance over the current fleet; minimizing ownership costs by maximizing commonality, fuel efficiency, reliability, and maintaining effective competition throughout the life cycle. Commonality of components, maintenance procedures, training, etc., among vehicles are inherent in FoV solutions across mission variants to minimize total ownership cost. Unique service requirements have been minimized.

The approved Full Rate Production (FRP) joint cost position incorporates validated requirements identified during Multi-Service Operational Test and Evaluation (MOT&E) as well as other mission critical requirements identified by the warfighter and supported in the FY21 budget request. JLTV achieved a successful FRP decision in June 2019.

The FRP decision documented the requirement for improved situational awareness and external noise reduction. These requirements were identified during MOT&E and documented in the DOT&E report.  The program will procure and install new rear doors with larger windows, an external forward facing camera, and mufflers. Also, the Marine Corps will procure Troop Seats to provide Fleet Marine Forces with the ability to move troops in utility vehicles when tactical conditions allow unprotected troop transport. This requirement was codified in a Capability Requirement Change (CRC) letter for the JLTV program.  

A LRIP fixed price contract was awarded to Oshkosh Defense LLC on 25 August 2015. This contract consists of a three year LRIP period with options for five additional years of FRP deliveries. JPO JLTV procured the Technical Data Package (TDP) with appropriate data rights to allow for possible future competition for production vehicles and spares. Current contract options may be exercised through 30 November 2023 assuming contractual quantity headspace is still available. Current funding indicates headspace quantity of 16,901 may be achieved in FY 2021, with competitive follow on contract award anticipated in FY 2022.

Justification.val:
FY 2019: $572.774M
Procured 1,642 LRIP vehicles, kit procurement, System Technical Support, Engineering Change Orders, Vehicle Retrofits, Production Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM), Fielding support, Interim Contractor Support and Program Management support.   

The kits supported the baseline vehicle by providing the warfighter the ability to augment the vehicle's configuration to meet required vehicle capabilities such as fording, survivability, hot and cold weather operations, communications/C4I, combat bumpers, winches, and troop seats, etc, in order to respond to environmental conditions or threat situations.
 
FY 2020: $555.648M
Includes the procurement of 1,264 vehicles and kit procurement, Total Package Fielding (TPF) to include Support Equipment, Initial Spares, First Destination Transportation and vehicle storage, Performance Verification Testing (PVT), System Technical Support (STS), Production Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM), Engineering Change Orders (ECO)s and Retrofits and Interim Contractor Support (ICS). 

Fielding cost increased from the FY20 request due to the addition of support equipment and special tool kits to provide the units with the additional tools necessary to maintain the vehicles. Fielding includes increased support for harvesting existing communications, C4I, and Gun Protection Kits from HMMWVs to JLTVs.  Also the Marine Corps requirement for B-Kit armor at 100% of vehicles requires retrofit of a number of procured vehicles leading to increased support for installation during the fielding process

FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $381.675M
Pojects will include the procurement of 752 vehicles; various kits associated with mission and vehicle variant; fielding to include Total Package Fielding (TPF) which consists of travel and labor for multiple fielding teams to conduct concurrent fielding events at USMC bases and stations in Okinawa, Hawaii, North Carolina, and California, Support Equipment, Initial Spares, First Destination Transportation (FDT) and vehicle storage; Performance Verification Testing (PVT); System Technical Support (STS); Contractor Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM); Engineering Change Orders (ECO)s and Retrofits necessary to incorporate changes identified during manufacture on the production line and through operational assessments;  and Interim Contractor Support (ICS) which provides vendor support for maintenance and repair of JLTVs between initial fielding and the transition of sustainment to an organic capability; procure 74 JLTV companion trailers and associated kits, Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP) and First Destination Transportation. 

Kits will consist of mission essential equipment specific to each vehicle and variant and provide the warfighter the ability to augment the vehicle's configuration to meet required vehicle capabilities such as fording, survivability, hot and cold weather operations, communications/C4I winches, etc, in order to respond to environmental conditions or threat situations. Kit procurement includes up to 75 individual kits options for each vehicle.  

Funding in this line has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.

Name.@footnote: The JLTV LRIP and FRP production contract was competitively awarded to Oshkosh Defense in 2015.  The contract between the Government and Oshkosh includes priced option years through the end of the first contract period (Base plus 8 options). These contracted prices are not negotiable on a year to year basis. Vehicle and kit costs are based on the firm fixed price contract cost, quantity ranges, and option year. These ranges are dependent on total quantities procured across all Services based on both platform and variant. The unit costs are based on contract pricing of the manufacturers projected overhead and commodities forecast (i.e. raw materials, petroleum, and forward pricing rate agreements with labor unions) and are reflected in the contract. The Government agreed to these fixed and non-negotiable prices at the time of the competitively awarded JLTV production contract.  The production rates provided in this exhibit are annual estimates. Oshkosh's main production line is not wholly JLTV and has been set up to run multiple other Military Tactical and Commercial Business vehicles on the same line during the same shift. As such they do not have a unique JLTV 1-8-5.  The FY 2020 total vehicle quantity cost decreased from the FY20 request due to the documented requirement for improved situational awareness (new rear doors with larger windows and an external forward facing camera) and external noise reduction (addition of muffler). These requirements were identified during MOT&E and documented in the DOT&E report.  The program will also procure Troops seats and mission critical special tools.   Funding decrease from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $126.136M is due to the reduction of 512 vehicles in FY21 based on available budget.    The unit cost increases from FY 2020 to FY 2021 based on the fixed and non-negotiable prices on the JLTV production contract. Vehicle variant mix and final quantities of all services will affect the unit cost based on range pricing; as well as approved changes to the base vehicle.
MS C and contract award occured on 25 August 2015. Production rates for the JLTV variants are shown as annual rates.

FiscalYear.@footnote: Due to quantity and budget limitation of the Continuing Resolution, JLTV quantities were procured in mulitple contract awards..  106 vehicles were procured in Dec 2016 and 106 vehicles were procured in Jul 2017.

Due to quantity and budget limitation of the Continuing Resolution, JLTV quantities were procured in mulitple contract awards..  192 vehicles were procured in Dec 2017. The balance of 335 vehicles  procured in June 2018.

Due to quantity and budget limitation of the Continuing Resolution, JLTV quantities were procured in mulitple contract awards..  53 vehicles were procured in Dec 2019. The remaining will be procured in Feb 2020 (1151) and in June 2020 (60).

Name.@footnote: Engineering Change Orders (ECOs) and retrofit of design changes to vehicles produced and delivered are based on results from observations during manufacture on the production line and through operational assessments, such as MOT&E and others.   The funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $1.509M is to incorporate vehicle changes identified during manufacture on the production line and through operational assessments.

Kits consist of mission essential equipment specific to each vehicle and variant and are necessary for the various operational requirements. Procurement includes up to 75 individual kit options for each individual vehicle. Kits may include, but are not limited to, armor kits required for force protection and survivability, tactical communications kits, which provide net-ready capabilities, and operational kits that complement base vehicle functionality to achieve requirements for tactical employment and mobility. Final kit procurement density is subject to change and based on operational and mission profile at time of award. A vehicle to kit ratio will not accurately capture kit cost as they are dependent on varying factors and are tied to unit and operational requirement.    The FY 2020 kit cost increased from the FY20 request due to the requirement to procure Troop Seats to provide Fleet Marine Forces with the ability to move troops in utility vehicles when tactical conditions allow unprotected troop transport.   Funding decrease from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $39.303M is due to the vehicle quantity reduction in FY21 and the fielding requirements of each individual unit.

JLTV companion trailer is purpose built to comply with JLTV requirements for mobility and payload. Infantry battalion expeditionary mobility will be improved by pairing JLTV with its companion trailer, enabling the unit to keep pace with vehicle formations.   The increase of $4.121M in FY21 procures 74 trailers and associated kits, Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP) and First Destination Transportation.

ICS provides vendor support for maintenance and repair of JLTVs between initial fielding in FY19 and the transition of sustainment to an organic capability planned to begin in FY22. ICS continues in support of Operator New Equipment Training (OPNET) into FY23.  Funding increase from FY20 to FY21 of $1.133M is due to the increase of Interim Contract Support (ICS) to support the cumulatively fielded JLTV vehicles.

Program management includes the Government Systems Integration Laboratory operations in support of fielding requirements and the addition of Liaison Officers on-site at each MEF providing support for MEF mission readiness, and the resolution of maintenance related issues. The Liaison Officers coordinate between OPFORs, the JLTV program office, logistics managers and the vehicle manufacturer.  There is a minimal funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $.064M due to increased program management and travel required to support ongoing fielding.

Funding increase for Contractor SEPM costs from FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $2.103M is the result of increases in the transition of HMMWV based capabilities to JLTV.  This cost element provides for additional Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) engineering to conduct the necessary analysis to ensure required existing capabilities that reside on the operational HMMWV fleet are transitioned to the JLTV platform.

Production Verification Testing (PVT) which is limited reliability and performance testing conducted yearly to verify consistent design and manufacturing; testing related to ECP change to evaluate the successful integration on the vehicle and provide data for decision makers; Continued Command, Control, Communications, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) testing necessary for the integration of various weapons platforms.  Funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $.908M is for testing to validate vehicle performance for weapons platforms planned for integration in the FY21 timeframe.

Total Package Fielding (TPF) of JLTVs to Fleet Marine Forces includes the First Destination Transportation (FDT) for vehicles and kits, and all ancillary equipment required to conduct initial fielding and training to receiving units. Costs also include travel and labor for 3 fielding teams to conduct concurrent fielding events at multiple USMC bases and stations around the globe.  The FY20 fielding cost increased $22.047M from the FY20 request to the FY21 request is due to the increase of manpower and resources required to stand up fielding sites at I MEF and II MEF.   Fielding includes support for harvesting existing communications, C4I, and Gun Protection Kits from HMMWVs to JLTVs.  Also the Marine Corps requirement for B-Kit armor to 100% of vehicles requires increased support for installation during the fielding process.  Funding decrease from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $18.403M is due to the reduction in the support equipment and special tools. The program applies a horizontal fielding strategy that requires common support equipment and tools upon receipt of vehicles. Based on the simultaneous fielding schedule, in FY21 the need for special tools and support equipment declines.

Name.val: 3.8) Training Aids, Devices, Simulators and Simulations (TADSS)
